awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Interactive digital book series to provide world history for middle school to college students
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of an interactive digital book series focused on history education.  The proposed technology is aimed at middle and high school students, as well as first-year college students, preparing them for the AP World History: Modern exam covering 1200 CE to present, and for success across a broad swathe of standards-aligned history assessments.  Informed by research on digital youth culture, such as the work of Mizuko Ito, the proposed series recognizes the importance of informal, interest-driven learning and the role of technology in shaping modern education. Thomas and Brown's "A New Culture of Learning" highlights the significance of play, innovation, and imagination, all of which are embodied in the proposed series. By immersing and engaging students through meaningful choice, multimodal interaction design, and systems-based interpretations, the series emphasizes complexity, interdependencies, and causal connections in historical events. This interactive approach encourages students to perceive connections between past and present, making history more tangible and real. Ultimately, this approach takes history out of the textbook, placing students into the world of history itself, igniting their enthusiasm for learning about the past.  The project has the potential to improve historical literacy and critical thinking skills, fostering cultural awareness, empathy, and global citizenship.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of an educational technology that combines digital technology, multimedia, and game-based learning principles. It employs the "Psychosocial Moratorium," "Identity," and "Multimodal" principles, which allow learners to take risks in a low-stakes environment, explore different identities, and engage with multiple modalities for a deeper understanding of history. The technology used involves mobile media, narrative design, and interaction design, providing a unique and immersive learning experience. The research informing this project comes from applied educational research and digital youth culture studies, underpinning the interactive and engaging nature of the technology. The technical results include a digital learning series that brings history alive, making it tangible, memorable, and enriching for students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

History Adventures: Advancing History Education Through Immersive Technologies

History Adventures is a National Science Foundation (NSF) funded project, supported through the I-Corps program, designed to transform history education for middle school, high school, and lower division college students. The project's central objective is to leverage emerging technologies to create interactive and immersive learning experiences that move beyond traditional textbook-based instruction, fostering deeper engagement and understanding of historical content.

The project team approached this challenge by developing a novel combination of digital storytelling techniques, interactive user interface design, and virtual reality (VR) technology. The flagship product, Plague of Athens VR, offers a first-person perspective of the first recorded pandemic in 429 BCE, placing the user in the role of a young Athenian physician. This immersive environment allows for active participation in historical scenarios, promoting experiential learning through decision-making and exploration. Plague of Athens VR is available across multiple VR platforms, including Meta Quest, Steam VR, and Pico VR, and has received industry recognition, including a Bronze Medal at the 2024 Reimagine Education Awards for Best Immersive Learning Solution.

Beyond the development of Plague of Athens VR, the project is actively exploring the integration of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Natural Language Processing (NLP). These technologies hold the potential to personalize the learning experience further, adapting content and pacing to individual student needs and providing dynamic, responsive interactions within the historical simulations.

A critical component of the project involved rigorous customer discovery. The team conducted over 100 interviews with educators, students, administrators, and educational technology professionals at major industry conferences, such as ISTE, Games For Change, and SIGGRAPH. This extensive data collection provided crucial insights into the needs and challenges of modern history education. Key findings revealed a strong demand for:

  • Increased Student Engagement: Active learning strategies are preferred over passive content consumption.
  • Real-World Relevance: Curricula should connect historical events to contemporary issues and student experiences.
  • Standards Alignment: Educational tools must integrate effectively with established curriculum standards.
  • Data-Driven Assessment: Educators require robust analytics to monitor student progress and inform instruction.
  • Budgetary Constraints: Solutions need to be cost-effective and adaptable to varying school resources.

These findings have directly informed the design and development of History Adventures' products. The project prioritizes interactive elements, compelling narratives, and the provision of data-driven insights to support effective teaching and learning.

Significant progress has been made in platform deployment, with Plague of Athens VR successfully ported to multiple VR platforms. A promotional video has been produced to broaden awareness of the product's capabilities. Furthermore, the project has established key relationships within the educational technology sector, creating pathways for future collaborations and dissemination.

The next phase of development will focus on several key areas. The team is actively pursuing additional funding to expand the content library, incorporating a broader range of historical periods and events. We are collaborating with curriculum specialists to achieve close alignment with national and state educational standards. We are exploring strategic partnerships with educational publishers and distributors to maximize market reach. And we are launching pilot programs in schools to evaluate the effectiveness of various access models.

The overarching goal of History Adventures is to fundamentally improve history education by making it more engaging, relevant, and effective. By integrating innovative technologies with sound pedagogical principles, the project aims to foster a deeper appreciation for the past and its profound connections to the present. The team behind History Adventures is committed to continued research and development, contributing to the evolution of educational technology while advancing methodologies for teaching and learning in the digital age.
